newsitem.title: USA: Economists see lower long-term rates ahead.
newsitem.headline: Economists see lower long-term rates ahead.

text.p: Long-term U.S. interest rates will continue to fall in coming months as the economy slows to a crawl, analysts said Wednesday.

By cutting the demand for capital, an expected economic slowdown could shave the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond to 6.0 percent next year, a level not seen since last winter and only slightly higher than the record low of 5.77 percent from October 1993.
That would give consumers a big lift by lowering loan rates on major purchases like homes and cars.
The yield on the bellwether bond dropped to 6.64 percent early Wednesday, its lowest level in nearly seven months, before rebounding slightly in late trade.
The bond's price, which moves in the opposite direction, soared nearly two full points Tuesday, its biggest one-day gain in 16 months.

"We are probably headed below 6.50 percent by the end of this year, and we could go as low as 6.0 percent by the end of 1997," said Michelle Colley Laughlin, Treasury market strategist at Prudential Securities Inc.
Analysts see slower economic growth ahead, which would allow interest rates to fall and bond prices to rise.
The Commerce Department Wednesday reported inflation-adjusted U.S. gross domestic product growth slipped to 2.2 percent in the third quarter after a 4.7 percent reading in the second quarter.
Prudential expects GDP growth to slow to a meagre 1.0 percent by the second half of 1997, lowering rates further.
"It will mostly be very positive news (for the Treasury market) about the economy" that drives rates lower, Laughlin added.
The Federal Reserve could also nudge long-term rates lower by cutting the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, for the first time since Jan. 31.
Prudential sees the central bank lowering the funds rate from its current target at 5.25 percent sometime in 1997, Laughlin said.
Current monetary policy is too tight, especially with the White House and congressional leaders talking of cuts in federal spending to eliminate the federal budget deficit, analysts said.
Meanwhile, consumer spending is slowing and a sharp rally by the dollar has made exports of U.S. goods more expensive, which could slow sales growth overseas.
History also shows GDP growth tends to slow in the year following a presidential election, Laughlin added.
"All these factors could lead to a more sustained economic slowdown in 1997," she said. "We could even raise speculation of a recession."
Michael Krauss, managing director and chief technical strategist at Chase Securities Inc., agreed with Laughlin that the T-bond will gain if the economy weakens further.
However, he said intermediate-dated Treasury paper could benefit even more than the bond. "The bond is not the asset of choice right now," he added.
